Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988) (2) EU; European Union Risk Assessment Report 2,2',6,6'-TETRABROMO-4,4'-ISOPROPYLIDENEDIPHENOL (CAS No. 79-94-7), Part II - Human Health, Final Report 2006. Available from, as of Nov 7, 2012: http://esis.jrc.ec.europa.eu/doc/risk_assessment/REPORT/tbbpaHHreport402.pdf (3) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Nov 9, 2012: http://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (4) Eriksson J et al; Chemosphere 54: 117-126 (2004)
Information.StringValue: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A, which has a vapor pressure of 1.37X10-8 mm Hg at 25 deg C(2), will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 3.6 days(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 3.0X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 deg C(SRC) that was derived using a structure estimation method(3). Particulate-phase 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A may be removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A absorbs UV light at wavelengths >290 and is susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(4).

Section.Description: Biodegredation

Information.Name: Biodegredation
Reference: (1) Chemicals Inspection and Testing Institute; Biodegradation and Bioaccumulation Data of Existing Chemicals Based on the CSCL Japan, Ministry of Internatl. Trade and Industry, Japan, ISBN 4-89074-101-1 (1992) (2) Great Lakes Chem Corp; Determination of the Biodegradability in a Sediment/Soil Microbial System on Tetrabromobisphenol A in Soil Under Anaerobic Conditions; 8/24/89; EPA Document No. 40-8998115; Fiche No. OTS0525505
Information.StringValue: AEROBIC: In the Japanese MITI test, 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A, present at 100 mg/L, reached 0% of its theoretical BOD in 14 days using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L(1). Half-lives ranging from 48 to 84 days were measured for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in a natural river sediment/water study(2). Less than 8% of the applied radioactivity was recovered as CO2 during this study(2). After 56 days, 44.7%, 64.2% and 60.8% of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A remained for initial concentrations of 10, 100, and 1000 ug/L, respectively(2).

Information.Name: Biodegredation
Reference: (1) Great Lakes Chem Corp; Determination of the Biodegradability of Tetrabromobisphenol A in Soil Under Anaerobic Conditions; 2/6/89; EPA Document No. 40-8998097; Fiche No. OTS0525513 (2) Voordeckers JW et al; Environ Sci Technol 36: 696-701 (2002) (3) Ronen Z, Abeliovich A; Applied Environ Microbiol 66: 2372-2377 (2000)
Information.StringValue: ANAEROBIC: 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A at 10 mg/kg soil was incubated in 3 different soil samples under anaerobic conditions; only 0.35, 0.10, and 0.03% of the initially applied radioactivity was recovered as CO2 in 64 days indicating that this compound is slowly mineralized(1). After 64 days, 43.7 to 57.0%, 53.4 to 65.0% and 89.5 to 90.6% of the parent was still present in the three soils suggesting that this compound may undergo primary degradation fairly quickly in some soils(1). The biodehalogenation of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was examined in anoxic estuarine sediment studies(2); near complete loss of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was observed within 55 days with the formation of bisphenol A and some 2,6-dibromobisphenol A(2). Using anaerobic sediment from a wet ephemeral desert stream bed contaminated with chemical industry waste, 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was nearly 80% degraded within 10 days of incubation with an intermediate formation of tri- and dibrominated bisphenol A metabolites and a final formation of bisphenol A(3).

Information.Name: Abiotic Degredation
Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Nov 9, 2012: http://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (2) Eriksson J et al; Chemosphere 54: 117-126 (2004) (3) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 7-4, 7-5  (1990) (4) Mill T, Mabey W; p. 209 in Environmental Exposure From Chemicals Vol I, Neely WB, Blau GE, eds, Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press (1985) (5) Eriksson J et al; Chemosphere 54: 117-126 (2004)
Information.StringValue: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 3.0X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 deg C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 3.6 days at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). Phototransformation studies of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in aqueous solution determined a uv absorption maximum at 310 nm, a quantum yield of 0.042 and decomposition rates ranging from 3.3X10-5 (at pH 5.5) to 6.8X10-4 (at pH 9) per second which correspond to a half-life range 17 minutes to 5.8 hours(2). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(3). Phenols can undergo sensitized photo-oxidation in surface waters exposed to sunlight via reaction with hydroxyl and peroxy (RO2) radicals with half-lives on the order of days to weeks at the water surface(4); therefore, photo-oxidation may have some importance as a fate process for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in natural water(SRC). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A absorbs UV light at wavelengths >290 and is susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(5).

Information.StringValue: BCF ranges of 30 to 341 and 52 to 485 were measured for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in carp (Cyprinus carpio) during an 8-week study at concentrations of 80 ug/L and 8 ug/L, respectively(1). A BCF value of 307 was measured in fathead minnow (Pimepahles promelas)(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these BCF values suggest the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate to high.

The pKa of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is 7.5(3), indicating that this compound will exist partially in anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(4).

Information.Name: Volatilization from Water/Soil

Information.StringValue: The Henry's Law constant for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is estimated as 4.1X10-8 atm-cu m/mole(SRC) derived from its vapor pressure, 1.37X10-8 mm Hg(1), and water solubility, 0.24 mg/L(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is expected to be essentially nonvolatile from water surfaces(2). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A's estimated Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected to occur(SRC). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure(SRC).

Information.Name: Sediment/Soil Concentrations
Reference: (1) Watanabe I et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 31: 48-52 (1983) (2) Watanabe I et al; Chemosphere 12: 1533-39 (1983) (3) DeCarlo V; Ann NY Acad Sci 320: 678-81 (1979) (4) de Wit CA; Chemosphere 46: 583-624 (2002) (5) de Wit C et al; Organohalogen Comounds 66: 34811-3816 (2004)
Information.StringValue: SEDIMENT: River sediment collected from the Neya River, Japan, in September 1981 contained approximately 20 ug/kg on a dry weight basis of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A(1). Marine sediments collected from estuaries in Japan other than from Osaka Bay contained 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A at concentrations of <0.5 ppb to 1.8 ppb, dry weight basis(2). Marine sediments collected from estuaries in Osaka Bay contained 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A at 0.5 to 4.5 ppb while river sediments collected in Osaka contained this compound at concentrations from 22 to 140 ppb(2). Sediment samples collected in Arkansas contained unreported concentrations of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A(3). Sediment samples upstream and downstream from a plastics plant contained 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentrations of 50 and 430 ng/g respectively(4). A sediment sample from the Tromso harbor (Northern Norway) contained a 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentration of 1.24 ng/g dry wt(5).

Information.StringValue: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 1116 workers (355 of these were female) were potentially exposed to 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A the US(1). Occupational exposure to 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A may occur through inhalation of dusts and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A via inhalation of ambient air and house dust. Use data indicate the general popultion may be exposed to 2,2',6',6-tetrabromobisphenol A via ingestion of food stored in reusable polycarbonate container products made from polymers incorporating 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A(2).[(1) US EPA; Inventory Update Reporting (IUR).
